um I've studied acting
um and I've been teaching it for a long
time uh I've been teaching it formally
since
1973 and I've taught in all kinds of
places and sometimes I've been required
um as would be the case not now in my
career but but certainly early in my
career on a faculty a faculty you
know um a faculty has to kind of achieve
something as a group and so a lot of
times um I've had to teach very uh
traditional things and very traditional
so um I'm I'm I know a lot
about um the varieties of methods that
there are uh for approaching acting and
I think think the best thing I heard
about it one of my teachers said that um
you know you you can't really talk about
acting directly everything that we know
to say is couched in metaphors that's
number one it's not like teaching
medicine or or teaching architecture or
even
music um because it has to do with uh
identity and we don't really understand
so much much about it and it's not
something we can touch or feel um and
the changes of identities have never
been for
example translated into music like
Musical music is translated into notes
we haven't really translated what we do
into something that can be constantly
replicated with a result that we can
anticipate so there's something about it
that's a little
mysterious and then the other thing is
um Ethel merman's son actually was one
of the most um um powerful uh teachers
that I had and he said simply you know
the actor's gift is the imagination and
then one very practical and gifted
teacher said you know acting is the
ability that believe that you are
someone else so uh people have all
different ways of talking about it but
the first comment I think is the most
honest it's all couched in
metaphors and so I studied a variety of
methods um people always made fun of me
in acting school because I was always
taking notes but I was very interested
in what is this how is it again that
people can change before my eyes and
along the way of my studying acting and
also my um teaching acting I began to
see that my students sounded um a lot
alike and so um I wanted to show them
that no human being talks like another
human being there are people who are
identical um like you can have an
identical twin of your voice like there
are people who sound exactly like a
sibling in the tone of voice but nobody
talks alike and so I thought that one
place to study identity would be in the
actual speech of a given person and
originally I was going around um
interviewing people uh because I wanted
to teach something about that about
individuality as it is captured in in in
the actual physical physiological
mechanism of making sounds um we are
linguistic
animals um and then along the lines of
doing that u i developed this method
through which I make plays which is that
I interview people um I take something
that they said and then I attempt to say
exactly what they said uh more than word
for word utterance for utterance because
I have come to see that it's in the way
the utterances themselves are
manipulated that identity comes forward
so that's what I've been um studying and
practicing for a very very long time and
I have to say the thing that's
unquenchable about me is something I
told you about earlier really what I
really really love to do um is to listen
to people and listen to stories and so
over the past well I guess I have to
admit it's a little for more than 30
years now um if I've been learning
anything it's um that I've been learning
more and more about listening and I I
never get tired of it never get tired
the goal is to tell a

for the very reasons that we've been

on an artistic level that the old idea
of the
single even the old idea of the single
author if you will is
flawed uh
because it takes ultimately many people
to tell the story of a community or the
story of a society so that sense of the
August
author who can come in and
speak for women and speak for men
I don't believe
that well what maybe your imagination is

imagination comes into play but before

man
feels or how another woman feels about

a set of
experiences that color my lens and I've

very interested in how that person
across the town across the street how
did they
think and understanding I could never

something that bothered me it was really
something I worried

position and by the way you know when I

I'm still me so did I really lose
anything
no in fact maybe I gained
something
um aesthetically and artistically what
I've been trying to contribute is
something about
details that you know maybe there's a
